qas.question: What was responsible for the decline in spreading commissions?

context: A <a2_0><a7_0><b11_0>Federal Trade Commission<b11_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/> report issued in <a8_0>1958<a8_0/> attempted to quantify the effect of antibiotic development on American public health. The report found that over the period <a1_0><b10_0>1946-1955<b10_0/><a1_0/>, there was a 42% drop in the incidence of diseases for which antibiotics were effective and only a 20% drop in those for which antibiotics were not effective. The report concluded that "it appears that the <a4_0><b13_0>use of antibiotics, early diagnosis, and other factors<b13_0/><a4_0/> have limited the epidemic spread and thus the number of these diseases which have occurred". The study further examined <a3_0><b12_0>mortality rates<b12_0/><a3_0/> for eight common diseases for which antibiotics offered effective therapy (syphilis, tuberculosis, dysentery, scarlet fever, whooping cough, meningococcal infections, and pneumonia), and found a <a5_0>56%<a5_0/> decline over the same period. Notable among these was a <a6_0>75%<a6_0/> decline in deaths due to <a0_0><b9_0>tuberculosis<b9_0/><a0_0/>.
